Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Faye McNeill of Columbia University who, in collaboration with Professors Hai-Lung Dai and Yi Rao of Temple University is investigating photochemical reactions related to atmospheric aerosols. Sunlight is the primary driving force in gas-phase atmospheric chemistry, but the importance of photochemistry occurring inside atmospheric aerosol particles or at the gas-aerosol interface is not well understood. Reactions involving the participation of light-absorbing organic aerosol components as photo-activators have been suggested as pathways for the photochemical origin and processing of important gas-phase species such as NO2 (nitrogen dioxide) and O3 (ozone). This project uses a combination of theory and experiment to investigate chemistry inside aerosols. The PIs have also developed an integrated education and outreach program consisting of three major thrusts: (1) AIRE, a Spanish/English bilingual blog and informational website targeted at students and educators (2) Research and curriculum development with local K-12 science educators, and (3) a teacher certification program designed to train midcareer and early retiree mathematics and science professionals as middle-school teachers

The proposed research is inspired by the hypothesis that photoactivated chemistry involving light-absorbing organic compounds inside atmospheric aerosol particles may lead to the formation of oxidized aerosol organic material, either via the direct oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) or via the formation of oxidizing radicals in the aerosol phase. This hypothesis is being tested her by a combination of experimental and modeling approaches designed to gain the necessary molecular-level insight into photoactivated aerosol chemistry. Advanced spectroscopic techniques, laser flash photolysis, and computational chemistry will be used to create new knowledge of the systems of interest at the molecular level. Aerosol flow reactor experiments are to be used to quantify the kinetics of these processes under aerosol conditions. The impact of this chemistry in the environmental context is to be evaluated via atmospheric chemistry modeling. This work is expected to provide insight into atmospheric aerosol chemistry with broader scientific impact on the impact of emitted gases upon air composition and derivative properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: We applied a powerful combination of experimental and modeling techniques to characterize photoactivator chemistry in atmospheric aerosols from the molecular to the process, regional and global scales. We used bulk phase aqueous chemistry including laser flash photolysis, and aerosol-phase reaction chamber and nonlinear optical studies to gain molecular-level insight into the mechanisms and kinetics of photo-enhanced chemistry in aerosols. In addition to fundamental insights into the mechanisms and kinetics of these processes, our findings represent the first in-situ observation of organic molecules at the gas-aerosol interface (1). We found that the molecules show a significant difference in surface binding of aerosols than those in the planar air/water interface. We also used numerical atmospheric chemistry modeling in order to extract kinetic parameters and assess the impact of these processes on atmospheric composition (2-3). We find that this pathway may be a significant contributor to aqueous aerosol SOA (aaSOA) formation under acidic conditions where other aaSOA formation mechanisms are less efficient. Our work has resulted in more than 10 presentations at ACS meetings, Gordon conferences, and Utah Air Quality meetings. Eight papers have been published under this support, with two more in preparation (1-8).

Broader Impact: The results of this project benefit society by improving our understanding of the impact of human activities on air quality and climate, and advancing our understanding of chemical processes that govern the production of fine particulate matter, on a molecular to environmental scale. The introduction of the SHS technique for aerosols was also a milestone contribution to the physical and analytical chemistry communities. Our research efforts were also complemented by an integrated education and outreach program designed to help fill a pressing societal need for scientific information about our changing environment, and attract and retain students from underrepresented minorities into STEM. These activities include mentoring high school researchers and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in the McNeill Group laboratory and the McNeill group bilingual (English/Spanish) online outreach program (http://outreach.mcneill-lab.org, Twitter: @AIRE_outreach). Over the course of the project, McNeill also assumed a leadership role in the Clean Air Toolbox for Cities initiative, a scalable approach to reduce air pollution and protect human health in cities across Africa and India by building technical capacity and developing science-based clean air solutions. Since joining USU, Dr. Rao, as a mentor, guides undergraduate students in ChemClub (ACS undergraduate student chapter at USU) since 2018. Rao has been actively involved in outreach programs, particularly focused on attracting and training students. Six of students from underrepresented in STEM disciplines were trained:  2 Native American students and 4 female students.Prof. Dai and his group participate in educational outreach through the Temple Noyce Teacher Scholars project.
